talk.author: did:plc:f56ftt2pbqtd5x3aee2e6g34
talk.utter: I think he used different materials in his street art. I suspect the morning show preferred to have him do chalk art rather than spray painting graffiti to make him more palatable to the middle class viewers. They need not have torn their hair out over property damage in the Reagan era of America.

talk.author: did:plc:k4h3pfoie2rqetkluqxvrcvz
talk.utter: I feel that art has become more familiar to me because of his constant thinking about how to make it visible and felt by as many people as possible. There was also art drawn with ink and brush when they came to Japan (I was not able to take pictures).

talk.author: did:plc:f56ftt2pbqtd5x3aee2e6g34
talk.utter: Like Banksy some decades later, he figured out how to assume mainstream popularity as a street artist becoming a pop artist. Attuned to a sort of gay scene and new wave + hip-hop sensibility translated from music to visual art, it feels like he was living in the 1990s a decade early.

talk.author: did:plc:f56ftt2pbqtd5x3aee2e6g34
talk.utter: Like Banksy some decades later, he figured out how to assume mainstream popularity as a street artist becoming a pop artist. Attuned to a sort of gay scene and new wave + hip-hop sensibility translated from music to visual art, it feels like he was living in the 1990s a decade early.

talk.author: did:plc:k4h3pfoie2rqetkluqxvrcvz
talk.utter: There was an explanation that he had been criticized by the art industry for commercializing his works. Nowadays, it is common for works to be made into goods, but back then it seems that such a trend was still in place. When you think about it, I think he was ahead of his time.

talk.author: did:plc:k4h3pfoie2rqetkluqxvrcvz
talk.utter: Sorry if it's hard to understand as it's a machine translation.

talk.author: did:plc:f56ftt2pbqtd5x3aee2e6g34
talk.utter: Seems to come through clearly in English. I meant that the impact of Keith Haring's commercialization of his art into merchandise has left me ambivalent. That has shaped the aspects of his work most popularly remembered, and the aspects that are conveniently forgotten by the mainstream.

talk.author: did:plc:f56ftt2pbqtd5x3aee2e6g34
talk.utter: Like Banksy some decades later, he figured out how to assume mainstream popularity as a street artist becoming a pop artist. Attuned to a sort of gay scene and new wave + hip-hop sensibility translated from music to visual art, it feels like he was living in the 1990s a decade early.

talk.author: did:plc:k4h3pfoie2rqetkluqxvrcvz
talk.utter: There was an explanation that he had been criticized by the art industry for commercializing his works. Nowadays, it is common for works to be made into goods, but back then it seems that such a trend was still in place. When you think about it, I think he was ahead of his time.

talk.author: did:plc:f56ftt2pbqtd5x3aee2e6g34
talk.utter: For better and for worse. I'm not quite sure what to make of the Keith Haring merchandise phenomenon. Maybe it has obscured his political art on issues like AIDS activism because people mainly see the happy dancing people on clothing and the like.
